div.p: Greetings. This evening, letters addressed to me were sent to a certain renowned merchant from our people and delivered by a certain messenger, but with an unknown author and without the author's name. You yourself will see what matter I am reminded of, for I have sent them enclosed with mine, so that you may read and judge. Indeed, a zeal for piety and love for our homeland is feigned; but because everything is useless, they are very suspicious to me. Perhaps some trickster or rogue wanted to fabricate these trifles and frighten us with such a tragic image and thus restrain us, so that we would not join our forces against the impious in any part; although in the meantime I admit it is prudent, in such slippery points of ulcerated times, to not rashly reject any admonition. But it will be yours to judge. Farewell.
St. Gallen, December 20, in the year 1550.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, his own.
